item.title: Characterizing the afternoon-to-evening transition
item.description: This project aims to improve our understanding of the complex land-atmosphere processes and their interaction during the afternoon to evening transition (AET). In particular, we propose to use a combination land surface and profiling observations together with large eddy simulation (LES) and mesoscale model simulations to better understand how the surface energy balance and lower atmosphere evolve during the AET.

item.title: Coupling snow sub-grid variability model into a land-surface model
item.description: This project aims to solve the spatial variability of snow depth problem in the Earth system modeling. A snow model for representing sub-grid variability of snow depth will be coupled into the Rapid Update Cycle Land Surface Model (RUC LSM), and its impacts on RUC LSM will be evaluated.

item.title: Wyoming Center for Environmental Hydrology and Geophysics (WyCEHG)
item.description: The Wyoming Center for Environmental Hydrology and Geophysics (WyCEHG) was established in July 2012 with a NSF grant. The goal of WyCEHG is to establish a center of excellence in environmental hydrology and hydrogeophysics. WyCEHG uses surface and subsurface hydrological models to link surface and groundwater.
